coredata.dc:title: Electron density modulation of MoP by rare earth metal as highly efficient electrocatalysts for pH-universal hydrogen evolution reaction

coredata.dc:description: Profiting from Pt-like electronic structure and high electrical conductivity, molybdenum phosphide (MoP) has received widespread attention as a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalyst. Although various effective strategies have been developed to regulate the bare MoP synthesis, the electrocatalytic performance of MoP is still far from satisfactory, especially in pH-universal applications. Recently, doping of heterogeneous elements, particularly for rare earth (RE) metals, has been emerged as an effective method to precisely regulate the local electronic structure of phosphides. Herein, the novel and controllable La/Yb-doped MoP nanoparticles encapsulated in nitrogen-doped carbon matrix (MoP@NC) are synthesized. The as-prepared La/Yb-doped catalysts (RE-MoP@NC (RE = La, Yb)) exhibit fantastic HER electrocatalytic performance for both activity and durability in a wide pH range. Detailed structural characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations validate that the electronic densities around Mo and P atoms are effectively tuned by La/Yb doping atoms, resulting in the optimization in Gibbs free energy of MoP toward the hydrogen adsorption, which can boost its intrinsic HER activity. This research enriches RE-modified catalysts and reveals that the RE metal doping can be extended to other non-noble metal catalysts as a general method.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: XRD patterns (a) and partially enlarged view (b) of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC. (c) The Raman spectra of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC. (d) XPS survey spectra of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC. The high-resolution XPS spectra for (e) Mo 3d and (f) P 2p of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC, respectively.
(a) TEM and (d) HRTEM images of MoP@NC. (b) TEM and (e) HRTEM images of Yb-MoP@NC. (c) TEM and (f) HRTEM images of La-MoP@NC. HAADF-STEM images of (g) Yb-MoP@NC and (h) La-MoP@NC.

Electrocatalytic performance of RE-MoP@NC toward HER in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte. (a) The IR-compensated polarization curves of different samples toward HER at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. (b) The corresponding Tafel slopes derived from LSV plots. (c) The overpotentials of various electrocatalysts at 10, 20, and 30 mA cm-2, respectively. (d) The capacitive currents at 0.375 V of the as-prepared samples. (e) Nyquist diagrams of different catalysts. (f) The LSV curves of La-MoP@NC in the first cycle and after 1000 cycles.

(a) The IR-compensated LSV curves of La-MoP@NC in alkaline, acidic, and neutral media. (b) The corresponding Tafel slopes. (c) i-t curves of La-MoP@NC at constant potentials for 12 h. (d) The IR-compensated LSV curves of Yb-MoP@NC in alkaline, acidic, and neutral media. (e) The corresponding Tafel plots. (f) i-t curves of Yb-MoP@NC at constant potentials for 12 h.

(a) Top view of the H adsorbed MoP pristine structure and the structures with the substitutional (S) La-dopant, the interstitial (I) La-dopant, and a combination of substitutional and interstitial (S + I) La-dopants on Mo-terminated surface (blue: Mo, gray: P, green: La, and pink: H). HER free energy diagrams for various configurations of pristine and RE-metal-doped MoP: (b) La on Mo-terminated surface, (c) Yb on Mo-terminated surface.

head.ce:title: Electron density modulation of MoP by rare earth metal as highly efficient electrocatalysts for pH-universal hydrogen evolution reaction

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: N-doped carbon encapsulated rare-earth-metal-doped MoP nanoparticles (RE-MoP@NC) with regulated electron density and abundant active sites serve as high-efficiency HER catalystsin pH-universal range.

Profiting from Pt-like electronic structure and high electrical conductivity, molybdenum phosphide (MoP) has received widespread attention as a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalyst. Although various effective strategies have been developed to regulate the bare MoP synthesis, the electrocatalytic performance of MoP is still far from satisfactory, especially in pH-universal applications. Recently, doping of heterogeneous elements, particularly for rare earth (RE) metals, has been emerged as an effective method to precisely regulate the local electronic structure of phosphides. Herein, the novel and controllable La/Yb-doped MoP nanoparticles encapsulated in nitrogen-doped carbon matrix (MoP@NC) are synthesized. The as-prepared La/Yb-doped catalysts (RE-MoP@NC (RE = La, Yb)) exhibit fantastic HER electrocatalytic performance for both activity and durability in a wide pH range. Detailed structural characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations validate that the electronic densities around Mo and P atoms are effectively tuned by La/Yb doping atoms, resulting in the optimization in Gibbs free energy of MoP toward the hydrogen adsorption, which can boost its intrinsic HER activity. This research enriches RE-modified catalysts and reveals that the RE metal doping can be extended to other non-noble metal catalysts as a general method.

ce:section.ce:para: Clean and renewable hydrogen energy has been regarded as the most promising alternative to the traditional fossil fuels [1,2]. Electrochemical water splitting, involving cathode hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and anode oxygen evolution reaction (OER), is widely considered to be the simplest, environmentally friendly, and efficient hydrogen production technology [3–5]. To date, platinum and its compounds are still dominated in HER as their high catalytic activities but severely limited by their low abundance and high cost [6,7]. In addition, the pH values of electrolytes in practical HER process and various industrial applications are different [8–11]. Thus, the development of low-cost, high-efficient, and pH-universal non-precious metal catalysts is essential for water electrolysis.

Tremendous efforts have been devoted to developing various non-noble metal catalysts. Among these candidates, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are widely regarded as the most promising catalysts due to their excellent HER performance and superior chemical stability [12,13]. In particular, molybdenum phosphide (MoP) has received widespread attention owing to its Pt-like electronic structure and high electrical conductivity [14–16]. However, pristine MoP usually exhibits unsatisfactory catalytic activity, caused by its low active sites content and strong hydrogen bonding ability. Therefore, it remains a challenge to coordinate high intrinsic activity and fast reaction kinetics [17–20]. Various effective strategies have been widely investigated to improve the electrocatalytic performance of MoP-based nanomaterials, such as adjusting the electronic structure, particle size, surface, and interface of the catalysts [21–24]. Incorporating heterogeneous elements into MoP lattice has been emerged as an effective method to adjust electronic structure of MoP, which can accelerate the electron transfer and optimize the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption, thus promoting its catalytic activity. Yang et al. reported S-doped MoP nanoporous layers for high-efficiency HER in pH-universal electrolytes, which is attributed to the high electron mobility after S doping [25]. Zhang et al. demonstrated that Co/Ni-doped MoP hybrid electrocatalysts show outstanding HER catalytic activity in pH-universal electrolytes, and the charge transfer caused by transition metal doping makes for their high catalytic activity [26]. These studies have revealed that the doping of foreign elements plays a vital role in improving the HER performance.

More recently, rare earth (RE) elements have attracted ever-increasing attention in electrochemical utilizations owing to their partially filled 4f orbitals and lower electronegativity [27,28]. Theoretically, when doping RE elements into host materials, RE metal atoms will donate electrons and change the surrounding electronic environment of the host material atoms, owing to the difference in electronegativity between RE metal and host material elements [29,30]. However, RE-element-doped TMPs have so far been rarely reported. Qu and co-workers reported for the first time that Ce-doped CoP catalysts exhibit superior HER catalytic performance from experimental and theoretical aspects [31]. Yang and co-workers demonstrated that Er-doped CoP nanomeshes are good electrocatalysts for overall water splitting [32]. Previous researches proved that RE element doping can be an effective method to adjust the electronic structures of catalysts and promote the dissociation of water to form active hydrogen adsorbates. However, it is still a challenge to dope RE metal atoms into other electrocatalysts, due to the huge difference in atomic radius between RE elements and other transition metals. Additionally, RE-metal-doped MoP is rarely reported, and the effect of RE metal doping on the catalytic activity of MoP needs to be revealed.

Herein, we reported the synthesis of RE-metals (La and Yb)-doped MoP nanoparticles encapsulated in nitrogen-doped carbon (MoP@NC), which are denoted as RE-MoP@NC (RE = La, Yb), using a simple solid-phase method combined with subsequent heat treatment. The as-prepared RE-doped catalysts exhibit superior electrocatalytic HER performance in pH-universal range. The Yb-MoP@NC only needs the potentials of 136.5, 148.5, and 250.1 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline, acidic, and neutral media, respectively, and even lower overpotentials can be achieved in La-MoP@NC electrode (129.3 mV in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, 142.18 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte, and 235.27 mV in 1.0 M PBS electrolyte). XPS results and density functional theory (DFT) calculations validate that RE metals doping can tune the electronic densities around Mo and P atoms, thus adjust the electronic states and optimize the Gibbs free energy of MoP toward the hydrogen adsorption, which can boost its intrinsic HER activity.

Melamine (C3H6N6), ammonium dihydrogen phosphate (NH4H2PO4), and ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent (Shanghai, China). Lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3∙6H2O) and ytterbium nitrate (Yb(NO3)3) were obtained from Aladdin Reagent (Shanghai, China). The commercial 20% Pt/C and 5 wt% Nafion solution were bought from Johnson Matthey Chemicals (Shanghai, China) and Sigma-Aldrich, respectively. All the chemicals were employed directly without further purification or treatment. High-purity water used throughout the experiment was prepared using Millipore system.

The MoP@NC was synthesized through a simple solid-phase synthesis process followed by a high temperature heat treatment. Typically, 2.35 g of melamine was first put into a mortar. Then, 1 mmol (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 4 mmol NH4H2PO4 were added and ground into a homogeneous powder. Subsequently, MoP@NC was prepared by the pyrolysis of the as-prepared powder above at 800 °C in Ar/H2 (10%) for 2 h, where a heating speed of 5 °C min−1 was utilized.

RE-MoP@NC (RE = La, Yb) was prepared using the same procedure as MoP@NC. In a typical procedure of preparations for RE-MoP@NC, 2.35 g of melamine, 0.95 mmol (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 0.35 mmol RE nitrate, and 4 mmol NH4H2PO4 were thoroughly ground into a homogeneous powder (RE:Mo = 0.05:0.95). The subsequent heat treatment process was the same as that of MoP@NC, and the obtained products with 5% doping amount were denoted as La-MoP@NC and Yb-MoP@NC. For exploring the influence of the doping contents of RE element on catalytic performance, RE:Mo ratios of 0.025:0.975 and 0.1:0.9 were also considered, which produced another four samples marked as 2.5% La-MoP@NC, 2.5% Yb-MoP@NC, 10% La-MoP@NC, and 10% Yb-MoP@NC, respectively.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted on PANalytical X’pert Pro X-ray diffractometer (Holland) with Cu Kα radiation under a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 40 mA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results were collected through Axis Ultra Dld-600W spectrometer (Kratos Analytical Ltd., Japan). Raman measurements were conducted by the LabRAM HR instrument (Horiba JobinYvon). Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Quanta 650 FEG, USA) and transmission electron microscopy coupled with an energy-dispersive spectrometer (TEM and EDS, FEI Talos F200X, USA) were performed to investigate the morphologies and nanostructures of catalysts. The specific surface areas of catalysts were recorded using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore-size distributions were calculated through the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model.

All electrochemical measurements were carried out in a three-electrode electrochemical system at room temperature using the CHI-760E electrochemistry workstation. The glassy carbon electrodes (GCE, diameter = 5 mm) loaded with the as-prepared catalysts were employed as the working electrodes and graphite rod was utilized as the counter electrode. Ag/AgCl electrode was adopted as the reference electrode in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte (pH = 0) and 1.0 M phosphate buffer saline (PBS) electrolyte (pH = 7). Hg/HgO was used as the reference electrode in 1.0 M KOH (pH = 14). All potentials in the whole experiment were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE).

The working electrodes was prepared as follows: 10 mg catalyst powder and 20 μL Nafion were first added into the mixed solution (490 μL water and 490 μL ethanol) by ultrasonic dispersion to obtain catalyst ink; next, 40 μL of the ink was loaded on the GCE and the loading mass of catalysts were 2.0 mg cm−2. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were measured at 5 mV s−1 with IR-compensated in alkaline, acidic, and neutral media. The Tafel plots were derived from the corresponding LSV curves. The long-term stability of catalysts was evaluated by amperometric current density-time (i-t) measurements at a constant potential which was obtained according to LSV curves at 10 mA cm−2 in different electrolytes. Accelerated durability tests (ADT) were carried out by conducting 1000 CV cycles with a scan speed of 100 mV s−1 in alkaline medium. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were performed at −0.15 V (vs. RHE) in alkaline medium with the frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with an AC amplitude of 5 mV.

The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) with projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials was employed to prove the effectiveness of La and Yb dopings to improve the HER performance of MoP [33,34]. Generalized gradient approximation with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) functional was utilized to depict the electron exchange and correlation energies [35,36]. The plane wave cutoff energy of all models was set as 450 eV. The energy difference and the force tolerance were set to be 1 × 10−5 eV and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. The partial occupancy for each orbital was set by Gaussian smearing method with a sigma value of 0.1 eV. In addition, spin polarization was also considered. The Brillouin zone of all slab models was sampled by 7 × 7 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid.

The MoP bulk was fully relaxed with the lattice parameters adjust to a = b = 3.230 Å and c = 3.21 Å, which is similar to the experiment results. In all the calculations, a three-layers thick p (2 × 2) (001) plane of MoP unit slab with 15 Å vacuum was used to simulate the MoP surface [37]. The bottom layer atoms were fixed to mimic the adsorption of hydrogen to the surface of catalysts.

As the total path of hydrogen evolution reaction can be written as:
H+ + e− → 1/2H2

the Gibbs free energy of adsorbed hydrogen is calculated by:
ΔGH*=ΔEH*+ΔZPE-TΔS
where ΔEH*, ΔZPE, and ΔS are the hydrogen adsorption energy, the zero-point energy change and entropy change of adsorption hydrogen, respectively. In our calculations, ΔEH* is calculated by ΔEH* = Eslasb+H* - (Eslasb+ EH*), where Eslasb+H*, Eslasb, and EH* are the total energy of the surface hydrogen adsorbed slab model, the energy of slab model, and half the energy of a single gaseous molecule of hydrogen, respectively. Additionally, ΔZPE and TΔS are calculated by using equations ΔZPE = ZPE(H*) - 1/2ZPE(H2) and TΔS = TS(H*) - 1/2TS(H2) ≈ -1/2TS(H2). Specifically, ZPE(H*) is calculated from the vibration frequency. ZPE(H2) and TS(H2) are obtained from the published results [38].

The MoP@NC nanoparticles were synthesized through a simple solid-phase method combined with subsequent heat treatment, in which NH4H2PO4 and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O were used to synthesize MoP and C3H6N6 was employed to form the nitrogen-doped carbon coating. RE-metal-doped samples RE-MoP@NC (RE = La, Yb) were synthesized by adding RE nitrates during the preparation process of MoP@NC.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) was employed to investigate the phase and structure of the as-prepared samples, which is shown in Fig. 1 a. XRD patterns present that all diffraction peaks match well with the hexagonal MoP phase, indicating well-defined MoP was successfully synthesized and the crystal structure will not change with RE metal doping [39]. Notably, a small amount of molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) is formed, and the peak near 40 degrees corresponds to the (101) plane of Mo2C phase. Interestingly, the partially enlarged XRD patterns (Fig. 1b) reveal that the peak (101) of MoP phase shifts slightly to a low angle with La/Yb doping, which is attributed to lattice expansion caused by the larger ionic radius of La3+ and Yb3+, suggesting that La and Yb are successfully introduced into the MoP lattice [40].

As displayed in Fig. 1c, Raman spectra of the as-prepared catalysts all show two typical peaks of carbon matrix located at 1340 and 1580 cm−1, which are assigned to D band and G band, respectively, indicating that melamine decomposes into nitrogen-doped carbon coating [41,42]. The ID/IG values of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC were calculated to be 1.1, 1.05, and 1.04, respectively, reflecting the increase of local graphitization degree after RE metal doping, which can effectively promote the electron transfer rate [28].

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were conducted to explore the surface composition, electronic structure, and valence state of the as-prepared samples. As demonstrated in Fig. 1d, the full survey spectra exhibit the presence of Mo, P, C, N, and O elements in all samples, and the obvious peaks of Yb/La emerge in Yb-MoP@NC/La-MoP@NC catalysts. Fig. S1a and b display the high-resolution spectra of Yb 4d and La 3d, which further confirm that Yb and La elements have been successfully incorporated into MoP lattice. In addition, the high-resolution spectra of Mo 3d and P 2p were fitted to investigate the influence of Yb/La doping on the electronic structure of MoP. The high-resolution Mo 3d spectra of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC are demonstrated in Fig. 1e, in which three pairs of characteristic peaks can be found. The predominant peaks centered at 228.28 and 231.48 eV can be ascribed to Moδ+ 3d5/2 and Moδ+ 3d3/2 of partial positive-charged molybdenum species (Moδ+, 0 < δ < 4) of MoP@NC, the deconvoluted peaks located at 229.02 and 232.15 eV are ascribed to Mo4+ 3d5/2 and Mo4+ 3d3/2, and the other two low intensity peaks at 233.18 and 235.55 eV are assigned to Mo6+ 3d5/2 and Mo6+ 3d3/2, which are due to the surface oxidation of molybdenum species (MoO2 and MoO3) [17,43]. Three pairs of peaks for Moδ+, Mo4+, and Mo6+ are similarly observed in Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC, but compared to MoP@NC, the ratio of Moδ+ is significantly increased after Yb/La doping, owing to the differences of electronegativities between Yb (1.1)/La (1.1) and Mo (2.16), which results in the electron transfer from Yb/La to Mo. It can be clearly observed that Mo 3d peaks after Yb/La doping moved toward lower binding energies, suggesting the electron densities around the Mo atoms are increased [26,29]. The increase in the electron density of the Mo species can adjust the electronic state of catalysts and facilitate the adsorption of hydrogen, thus enhancing its intrinsic catalytic activity. Two pairs of peaks can be observed in the high-resolution P 2p spectra (Fig. 1f). The double peaks located at 129.52 and 130.34 eV are indexed to Pδ- 2p3/2 and Pδ- 2p1/2, while the other two peaks of P-O 2p3/2 and P-O 2p1/2 at 133.5 and 134.3 eV are due to oxidized phosphate species in air. The ratio of Pδ- increases obviously and the binding energy shifts negatively after Yb/La doping, indicating Yb/La donates electrons to P atoms, which is beneficial for the catalysts to capture protons more efficiently, thereby improving HER activity [44,45]. In the N 1s spectra (Fig. S1c), three peaks located at 398.27, 399.57, and 401.69 eV are assigned to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, and graphitic-N, while the peak located at 394.29 eV is attributed to Mo-N bond [46]. Fig. S2 displays the high-resolution C 1s peaks at binding energies of 284.8, 286.04, and 288.5 eV that can be ascribed to CC, CN, and CC, respectively. It can be seen that the peak area ratio of the CC bond increases significantly after RE metal doping, indicating that the graphitization degree increases. The specific peaks and binding energy values of the as-prepared samples are listed in Table S1. The element contents in the as-prepared catalysts were also explored by XPS spectroscopy, and the analysis results are shown in Table S2.

The morphology and microstructure of the as-prepared catalysts were studied by field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) and field-emission transmission electron microscope (FE-TEM). As displayed in Fig. S3, FE-SEM images of all samples show similar morphologies, presenting the aggregation of uniform small-sized nanoparticles, indicating that Yb/La doping has almost no effect on particle size and morphology of MoP@NC. Fig. 2 a-c exhibits the TEM images of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC, respectively. All samples are composed of uniformly cross-linked carbon-coated nanoparticles, and the average grain size is about 15 nm, which is in conformity with SEM images. Fig. 2d displays the high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) image of MoP@NC. A pair of fringes with interplanar spacing of 0.275 and 0.317 nm can be seen, indexed to the (100) and (001) plane of MoP. Notably, the lattice spacings of the (100) plane of Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC are 0.276 and 0.278 nm (Fig. 2e-f), respectively, which are much larger than that of MoP@NC, suggesting the incorporation of Yb/La elements increases the interplanar spacing, which agrees well with the XRD results [26]. In addition, a thin carbon layer of ∼2 nm on the surface of catalysts that caused by in-situ pyrolysis of melamine can be observed in all samples, which is beneficial to enhance electron transport and boost electrocatalytic activity [47]. The STEM-HAADF images of Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC are demonstrated in Fig. 2g, h, and Fig. S4, the elemental mapping images further prove that Mo, Yb/La, P, C, N, and O elements are evenly distributed in the catalysts, consistent with the XPS data. As shown in Fig. S5, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) measurement indicates that all samples hold typical type IV isothermal adsorption-desorption curves. The specific surface areas of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC are 12.05, 11.06, and 12.45 m2 g−1, respectively. The similar values of specific surface area also confirm that RE doping does not affect the morphology. Therefore, the improvement in electrocatalytic activity of RE-doped samples can be ascribed to intrinsic activity rather than morphology and particle size [48].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of Yb/La doping content on catalysts
ce:section.ce:para: In order to investigate the influence of Yb/La doping content, RE-MoP@NC catalysts with different doping ratios were prepared by adjusting the content of RE metal nitrate through the similar preparation process. Fig. S6 displays the XRD patterns of the samples with different doping ratios, showing the same diffraction peaks that match well with the MoP phase. The SEM images of RE-MoP@NC catalysts with different doping ratios are shown in Fig. S7. It can be seen that all catalysts are formed by the aggregation of uniform small-sized nanoparticles. To explore the effect of doping ratios on catalytic performance, we measured the HER activity of RE-MoP@NC catalysts in both 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte and 1.0 M KOH electrolyte. Fig. S8a exhibits the LSV curves of 2.5% La-MoP@NC, La-MoP@NC, and 10% La-MoP@NC in acid medium, in which the La-MoP@NC presents the best electrocatalytic activity. Using the formula η = k log(j)+m, where η is the overpotential, k is the Tafel slope, j represents the current density, and m is the Tafel constant, the Tafel slops were calculated. As displayed in Fig. S8b, La-MoP@NC shows the smallest Tafel slope of 58 mV dec−1 compared to the other two samples, indicating its excellent reaction kinetics. Fig. S8c presents the LSV curves of 2.5% Yb-MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and 10% Yb-MoP@NC, and the Yb-MoP@NC possesses the best electrocatalytic activity. As depicted in Fig. S8d, the Yb-MoP@NC also shows the smallest Tafel slope among the three samples. Furthermore, the catalytic performances of RE-MoP@NC catalysts with different doping ratios in alkaline medium are demonstrated in Fig. S9. Both the LSV curves and Tafel slopes manifest that the catalytic activity of RE-MoP@NC with 5% doping amount is the best.

Electrocatalytic activity of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC toward HER was first examined in alkaline electrolyte. As displayed in Fig. 3 a, IR-compensated LSV curves of the as-synthesized catalysts and the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C were measured at a scanning rate of 5 mV s−1. The commercial Pt/C catalyst has the best catalytic performance, which was used as a reference standard. The overpotentials of Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC are respectively 136.5 and 129.3 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which are lower than that of MoP@NC (172.59 mV). The mechanism and intrinsic properties of HER were studied by Tafel slopes. As presented in Fig. 3b, Tafel slopes of Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC are 70.84 and 57.84 mV dec−1, which are smaller than that of MoP@NC (79.29 mV dec−1), revealing that Yb/La doping improves the reaction kinetics. The values of Tafel slopes manifest that the HER of the as-prepared catalysts proceeds through a Volmer-Heyrovsky pathway. Fig. 3c exhibits the overpotentials of Pt/C, La-MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and MoP@NC at 10, 20, and 30 mA cm−2, respectively. The overpotentials of Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC at different current densities are smaller than that of MoP@NC owing to the Yb/La doping induced electron density distribution changes of MoP, which is beneficial to capture protons efficiently and enhance the catalytic activity of HER.

In order to further explore the underlying mechanisms that lead to the promoted HER performance of RE-doped MoP@NC, electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were conducted over all samples. The ECSA can be evaluated by measuring the double-layer capacitance (Cdl) within non-faradic range, which can reflect the effective active surface area of catalysts. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of MoP@NC-based catalysts were tested with various scan speeds between 20 and 120 mV s−1 (Fig. S10). Fig. 3d shows that the obtained Cdl values of Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC are 37.23 and 47.45 mF cm−2, respectively, which are larger than the undoped MoP@NC (31.23 mF cm−2), indicating that Yb and La doping can cause more active site exposure and effectively increase the electrochemical active surface area, which matches well with the improvement of catalytic activity [49,50]. Furthermore, the EIS measurements were employed to estimate the charge transfer kinetics at the interface of these catalysts. An equivalent circuit composed of solution resistance (Rs), constant phase element (CPE), double layer resistance (R1), and charge transfer resistance (Rct) was utilized to simulate Nyquist plots. Fig. S11 presents the schematic image of the equivalent circuit diagram, and the specific fitting results are listed in Table S3. It can be seen in Fig. 3e, Nyquist plots of these catalysts have similar shapes, indicating that the charge transfer processes on the electrode surface are similar. In addition, the Rct values of Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC are lower than that of MoP@NC, manifesting Yb/La doping can decrease charge-transport impedance and improve the electron transfer rate, thereby promoting the HER kinetics [51,52]. Fig. 3f shows the long-term durability of La-MoP@NC, which was evaluated by accelerated durability tests (ADT). The polarization curves of La-MoP@NC in the first cycle and after 1000 cycles are almost coincident, suggesting its outstanding electrochemical stability.

As the proton concentration in the electrolyte will change during practical application, it is necessary to develop a pH-universal catalyst. Thus, the HER performance of RE-MoP@NC was also estimated in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte (pH = 0) and 1.0 M PBS electrolyte (pH = 7). As depicted in Fig. 4 a, the overpotentials of La-MoP@NC are 142.18 and 235.27 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in acid and neutral media, respectively. The overpotential is the highest in the neutral medium among different electrolytes, due to the lower ion migration rate [53,54]. Fig. 4b presents that the Tafel slopes of La-MoP@NC obtained from the LSV curves are 58 and 141.13 mV dec−1 in acid and neutral media, respectively. In addition, the durability of La-MoP@NC was measured by i-t tests with a fixed potential at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline, acidic, and neutral media, which all exhibit excellent durability (Fig. 4c). Similarly, the HER performance of Yb-MoP@NC was also evaluated in alkaline, acidic, and neutral media. Fig. 4d displays that the overpotentials of Yb-MoP@NC in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte and 1.0 M PBS electrolyte are 148.53 and 250.1 mV and the corresponding Tafel slopes (Fig. 4e) are 68.44 and 168.37 mV dec−1, respectively. The ECSA and EIS measurements were also performed in both acid and neutral media. The obtained Cdl values of Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC in acidic medium (Fig. S15) are 16.13 and 20.82 mF cm−2, respectively, which are larger than the undoped MoP@NC (6.92 mF cm−2), indicating that Yb and La doping can cause more active site exposure and effectively increase the electrochemical active surface area. As displayed in Fig. S16, the obtained Cdl values of MoP@NC, Yb-MoP@NC, and La-MoP@NC in 1.0 M PBS solution are 2.83, 5.49, and 11.11 mF cm−2, respectively, which are consistent with their HER activities. Moreover, the EIS measurements were also performed at −0.3 V (vs. RHE) in 0.5 M H2SO4 and −0.2 V (vs. RHE) in 1.0 M PBS electrolytes, respectively. As demonstrated in Fig. S17, the charge transfer resistance values of Yb-MoP@NC (∼33 Ω) and La-MoP@NC (∼19 Ω) are smaller than that of MoP@NC (∼95 Ω) in acidic medium and the Rct values of Yb-MoP@NC (∼119 Ω) and La-MoP@NC (∼52 Ω) are also smaller than that of MoP@NC (∼229 Ω) in neutral medium, indicating Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC possess faster electron transfer rate than undoped MoP@NC during HER process in pH-universal ranges. The long-term durability of Yb-MoP@NC (Fig. 4f) was also measured in different electrolytes, which all shows outstanding stability. Fig. S18 exhibits the overpotentials of La-MoP@NC and Yb-MoP@NC at 5, 10, and 20 mA cm−2 in different electrolytes, respectively. All the above results indicate that La-MoP@NC and Yb-MoP@NC as HER catalysts have excellent electrocatalytic activity and superior cycle stability in pH-universal ranges.

DFT calculations of the adsorption free energy of hydrogen (△GH*) were carried out to further disclose the effect of La/Yb dopant in HER. Several optimized configurations based on RE-metal-doped MoP with Mo- or P-terminated surfaces were constructed, including the substitutional (S) of La/Yb-dopant on Mo-terminated surface, the interstitial (I) La/Yb-dopant on Mo-terminated surface, and a combination of substitutional and interstitial (S + I) La/Yb-dopants on Mo-terminated surface, the substitutional (S) of La/Yb-dopant on P-terminated surface, the interstitial (I) La/Yb-dopant on P-terminated surface, and a combination of substitutional and interstitial (S + I) La/Yb-dopants on P-terminated surface (Fig. 5 a and Fig. S19–S22). It can be seen that the hydrogen transfers from the pristine site in MoP to different sites in S structure, I structure, and S + I structure upon the introduction of Yb/La doping, indicating that the electronic structure is adjusted by the RE metal doping.

The Gibbs free energy of adsorbed hydrogen △GH* is widely used to evaluate catalytic activity of catalysts toward HER, with △GH* approaches zero indicating that there is a good balance between the proton reduction rate and H* desorption [55]. As shown in Fig. 5b and c, compared to pristine MoP, all La-doped and Yb-doped MoP structures with Mo-terminated surface possess more positive △GH*, demonstrating that La/Yb doping can effectively enhance HER activity of MoP. In addition, the lowest free energy for La-doped MoP with I structure is −0.09 eV (Fig. 5b), which is higher than the lowest free energy for Yb-doped MoP with S + I structure (−0.21 eV) (Fig. 5c), suggesting La doping is superior to Yb doping toward HER, which is in conformity with the experimental observations. Moreover, free energy diagrams for various structured La/Yb-doped MoP with P-terminated surface are also presented in Fig. S23. The lowest free energy (-0.16 eV) still appears in the I structure of the La-doped MoP with P-terminated surface (Fig. S23a), similar to the case with Mo-terminated surface, indicating that La-doped MoP will have the best catalytic activity when La exists in the crystal structure as interstitial atom. In contrast, the highest catalytic activity for Yb-doped MoP with P-terminated surface happens in the S structure (Fig. S23b), and meanwhile the free energy of the S structure is second only to the S + I structure for Yb-doped MoP with Mo-terminated surface, suggesting that Yb atoms are more inclined to replace Mo atoms in the crystal structure. To further investigate the effect of RE metal doping on the electronic structure of MoP, the density of states (DOS) for pristine MoP and various structured La/Yb-doped MoP with Mo-terminated surface are displayed in Fig. S24 and S25. The d-band center decreases from −0.59 eV to −0.72 eV in Yb-doped MoP with S + I structure and −1.39 eV in La-doped MoP with I structure, resulting in a loss in the binding strength of H, thereby promoting the desorption of H from the La/Yb-doped MoP surface. In addition, the differential charge density diagrams of the S structure, I structure, and S + I structure for La/Yb-doped MoP with Mo-terminated surface are also shown in Fig. S26 and S27. It can be seen that the charge density on the surface of Mo atoms decreases after La/Yb doping, thereby weakening the adsorption energy of La/Yb-doped MoP catalyst for H, which provides the intrinsic elucidation that La/Yb doping can effectively enhance the HER activity of MoP. The DOS and differential charge density diagrams of the different structures with P-terminated surface also reveal the similar trends, as shown in Fig. S28–S31, further demonstrating the underlying mechanisms that lead to the promoted HER performance of RE-doped MoP@NC.

In summary, we have successfully synthesized Yb/La-doped MoP coated with nitrogen-doped carbon via a simple solid-phase method with subsequent heat treatment. Benefiting from the increased electrochemical active area and exposed active sites, decreased charge transfer resistance, and the redistribution of charge density, the as-prepared Yb-MoP@NC and La-MoP@NC catalysts exhibit high-efficiency and durable hydrogen evolution catalytic performance in pH-universal electrolytes. Both experimental results and theoretical calculations confirm that the Yb/La dopings can cause charge transfer, greatly contributing to the modulation of electronic structure and reduction of the adsorption free energy of hydrogen, thereby enhancing the HER catalytic property of MoP. This research provides a general tactic for synthesizing highly active catalysts through RE metal doping, which can be extended to other material designs and applications.

Peng Wei: Designed and conducted the experiments, analyzed the data, and wrote the paper. Xiaogang Li: Performed the DFT calculations and wrote the paper. Zhimin He, Zesen Li, Xiaoyu Zhang, and Xueping Sun: Conducted the experiments and wrote the paper. Qing Li and Yunhui Huang: Guided data analysis. Hui Yang: Project administration, supervision, funding acquisition, and review & editing the manuscript. Jiantao Han: Project administration, supervision, and funding acquisition.
